quoteFirst: A native assured him that, within a circle of ten miles' radius, the children killed each year _would not exceed five hundred_. In Fokien province the crime was more general, and at a place called Kea King Chow there were computed to be from
quoteLast: hundred cases every month. A foundling hospital at Canton was named as preventing much of the crime, but it seems to have received only five hundred infants yearly; but a very small proportion of the births. The Chinese generally confess that infanticide is practiced throughout the empire, and is regarded as an innocent and proper expedient for lightening the pressure of poverty.
title: The History of Prostitution: Its Extent, Causes, and Effects throughout the World
author: Sanger, William W., 1819-1872

quoteFirst: We pointed out in the discussion of analog computers that the complexity and expense of increased accuracy was in direct proportion to the degree of accuracy desired. Happily for the digital machine, the reverse is true in its case. Increasing accuracy from
quoteLast: figures requires a premium of one-fifth, or 20 per cent. But jumping from 10-place to 11-place precision costs us only 10 per cent, and from 20-place to 21-place drops to just 5 per cent.
title: Computers—the machines we think with
author: Halacy, D. S. (Daniel Stephen), 1919-2002

quoteFirst: The natives of Uap, in number from
quoteLast: thousand, are of that perplexing type known generally as Micronesian, which covers a multitude of conjectures. The natives of each island have certain characteristics of form and features which make relationship to natives of other islands or groups of islands a possibility; but, on the other hand, there are such differences in language, in customs, in manner of living, that it is well-nigh impossible to state, with any degree of certainty, what or whence is the parent stock or predominant race.
title: The island of stone money
author: Furness, William Henry, 1866-1920

quoteFirst: Hogs sold at one dollar and fifty cents a hundred. Potatoes were considered high at ten cents a bushel, while quail sold at thirty cents a dozen. Butter brought from
quoteLast: cents a pound, and eggs six to eight cents a dozen.
title:
History of Linn County Iowa
From Its Earliest Settlement to the Present Time [1911]
author: Brewer, Luther Albertus, 1858-1933; Wick, Barthinius L. (Barthinius Larson), 1864-1947

quoteFirst: The dark blue solution now becomes yellow and the liquor shows all the characteristics of the indigo vat. It is necessary to keep the vat well stirred up during the time of setting, which takes from
quoteLast: hours. If there is much evolution of gas after this time it indicates that too much zinc powder has been added; this is a common fault with dyers, and such excess causes the vat to be too much disturbed and to work dirty. A lime-zinc vat, with occasional additions of new materials, keeps good for three months, and even then is in a better condition than the copperas vat.
title: The Dyeing of Cotton Fabrics: A Practical Handbook for the Dyer and Student
author: Beech, Franklin

quoteFirst: Russian law, this instrument should weigh from
quoteLast: pounds. It strikes like a triple lash upon the naked back of the sufferer. It does not plough or tear up the flesh like the knout, but the skin of course breaks under the heavy blows inflicted upon the spinal column and the sides.
title:
Continental Monthly , Vol. 5, No. 6, June, 1864
Devoted to Literature and National Policy
author: Various

quoteFirst: The men at arms of the dauphin's party, of whom the principal were, sir Pierre de Bourbon, lord of Prèaulx, Barbasan, and from
quoteLast: hundred noblemen and gentle dames, with the most notable inhabitants, were by command of the king of England, regent of France, carried to Paris under a considerable escort, and there imprisoned in the Châtelet, Bastille, the Temple, and other places.
title: The chronicles of Enguerrand de Monstrelet, Vol. 05 [of 13]
author: Monstrelet, Enguerrand de, 1390?-1453; Johnes, Thomas, 1748-1816 [Translator]

quoteFirst: More distant bodies would receive the intimation after intervals of time proportioned to their distances. Thus, if a body were one million miles away, the light would reach it in from
quoteLast: seconds, while over a distance as great as that which separates the earth from the sun the news would be carried in about eight minutes. We can calculate how long a time must elapse ere the light shall travel over a distance so great as that between the star and our earth.
title:
Young Folks' Library, Volume XI (of 20)
Wonders of Earth, Sea and Sky
author: Holden, Edward S. (Edward Singleton), 1846-1914 [Editor]

quoteFirst: From Concarneau to Quimperlé is a distance of above eighteen miles. The road runs near the sea, over a large tract of land covered with furze (ajonc), which, in Brittany, grows from
quoteLast: feet high, forming a solid impenetrable mass. Huge blocks of granite are scattered about in every direction, jutting out from among the furze—menhirs, cromlechs, and dolmens—a perfect wilderness of Celtic remains.
title: Brittany & Its Byways
author: Palliser, Bury, Mrs., 1805-1878

quoteFirst: *The Large Intestine.*—The large intestine is a tube from
quoteLast: feet in length and averaging about one and one half inches in diameter. It begins at the lower right side of the abdominal cavity, forms a coil which almost completely surrounds the coil of small intestine, and finally terminates at the surface of the body (Figs. 2, 71 and 73).
title: Physiology and Hygiene for Secondary Schools
author: Walters, Francis M. (Francis Marion), 1862-
